Safe HaskellNone

GameOfLife

Description

Contains everything related to Conway's Game of Life.

Synopsis
  • backgroundColor :: Color
  • cellColor :: Color
  • gridColor :: Color

simulateCell #

Arguments

:: Cell

The cell to simulate

-> Int

The number of alive neighbors

-> Cell

The resulting cell, after the simulation

Simulates a Cell with Conway's rules.

These are the rules:

  • An Alive cell lives with 2 or 3 alive neighbors
  • A Dead cell lives with exactly 3 alive neighbors
  • A cell with less than 2 or more than 3 neighbors dies

simulateGrid #

Arguments

:: Grid

The grid to simulate

-> Int

The index of the current cell

-> Grid

The resuling grid, after the simulation

Simulates a Grid with Conway's rules.

For exact rules see simulateCell

countCell #

Arguments

:: Cell

The cell to count | The resulting number. 1 if the cell is Alive, 0 otherwise.

-> Int 

Counts a single Cell.

Inserts a FigurePart at a given Grid and index

nextColor #

Arguments

:: Color

The previous color

-> Color

The next color

Returns the subsequent color to the specified color.

This is used to change the color of the cells.

The order is the following:

  • white
  • red
  • green
  • blue
  • yellow
  • cyan
  • magenta
  • rose
  • violet
  • orange

handleKeys #

Arguments

:: Event

The key event that has occured

-> GameData

The old game state

-> GameData

The new game state, after the key press was handled

Updates the game state depending on pressed keys. The following are interactable keys:

  • Space -> Pause and Unpause the game
  • Right Arrow -> Step one iteration forward
  • F1 -> Clear grid
  • F2 -> Create a random grid
  • F12 -> Change cell color (see nextColor)
  • R -> Reset grid
  • G -> Show / Hide grid
  • N -> Select next figure to place
  • LeftMouseButton -> Place selected figure at cursor

pixelPosToCellPos #

Arguments

:: (Float, Float)

The pixel coordinates

-> Position

The resulting cell coordinates

Converts pixel coordinates into cell coordinates

The cell coordinates start with (0, 0) at the top left corner but pixel coordinates start at the center of the window

update #

Arguments

:: Float

The time in seconds that has passed since the last call to this function

-> GameData

The old game state

-> GameData

The new game state, after stepping one iteration

Steps the game state one iteration forward.
